reasoning: The critique targets Section 5’s action-guidance move: acting more as if we’re in Scenario 3 rather than Scenario 1, and downweighting power-seeking. This is meaningfully connected to the paper’s practical upshot, but it’s not central to the paper’s main thesis about (non-)convergence and the role of trade/compromise, so centrality is moderate. The argument raises a plausible decision-theoretic concern (if Scenario 1 is ‘winner-take-all’, compromise-oriented strategies might have near-zero payoff there), but it doesn’t actually engage the paper’s quantitative comparison (marginal impact in Scenario 3 vs feasible power-multiplication in Scenario 1), nor justify that the ‘narrow target’ implies singleton control is the only workable approach. It also somewhat mischaracterizes the paper as “discarding Scenario 1” and as advocating “compromise” as the relevant strategy choice, when the text more cautiously argues to weight Scenario 3 more in expected-impact terms. Hence limited strength and only moderate correctness, despite decent clarity and focus.
title: Discarding unilateral control may forfeit the only viable strategy in harsh worlds
